Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 121 eligible children aged 13 years, who were scheduled for transthoracic echocardiography were randomized into three groups.

Participants.evidence: A total of 121 eligible children aged 13 years, who were scheduled for transthoracic echocardiography were randomized into three groups.

Intervention.evidence: They were treated with intranasal dexmedetomidine 1 mcg.kg −1 + esketamine 0.5 mg.kg −1 (group S1), dexmedetomidine 1 mcg.kg −1 + esketamine 1 mg.kg −1 (group S2), or dexmedetomidine 1 mcg.kg −1 + esketamine 1.5 mg.kg −1 (group S3).

Objective.evidence: In this study, we compared the different doses of intranasal esketamine combined with dexmedetomidine for sedation during transthoracic echocardiography in toddlers.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the success rate of sedation, other outcomes included HR, SpO 2 , onset time, wake-up time, and adverse effects.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: A total of 121 eligible children aged 13 years, who were scheduled for transthoracic echocardiography were randomized into three groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 121 eligible children aged 13 years, who were scheduled for transthoracic echocardiography were randomized into three groups.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The success rate of sedation was significantly higher in groups S2 (85.4%) and S3 (87.5%) than ingroup S1 (60%) ( p = 0.004).

Harms.evidence: However, there were no differences in the wake-up time or adverse effects among the three groups.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Clinical trial registration number: ChiCTR2200060976, 2022/06/14 (trail from August 2022 to January 2023)
